user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following get_rq_dauth_algo code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 21.17.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of get_rq_dauth_algo.
```c
static enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3
get_rq_dauth_algo (const struct MHD_RqDAuthParam *const algo_param)
{
  if (NULL == algo_param->value.str)
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5; /* Assume MD5 by default */

  if (algo_param->quoted)
  {
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))

      /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

    /* No known algorithm has been detected */
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
  }
  /* The algorithm value is not quoted */
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;

  /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

  /* No known algorithm has been detected */
  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
If the macro MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ expands to a routine that invokes a string/byte compare (e.g. memcmp/strncasecmp) using the provided length parameter directly, then passing algo_param->value.len as the compare length can cause the routine to read past the end of the concatenated token literal (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN) when algo_param->value.len is larger than the token length. In that case the token buffer would be accessed out-of-bounds and Rule 21.17 would be violated.
</scenario>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: The report is correct as a potential MISRA 21.17 violation. The code passes algo_param->value.len as the compare length to a macro (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ / MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n) while also passing a token that is a string literal (or two adjacent string literals that the preprocessor concatenates). If the macro expands to an operation that unconditionally reads 'len' bytes from the token pointer (for example memcmp/strncasecmp/memcmp-like implementation), and algo_param->value.len can be greater than the token literal’s storage (note a string literal has length N+1 including the terminating NUL), then the compare will read past the token object and thus violate Rule 21.17. This is a real possible fault unless the macro/implementation itself guards the compare length (e.g. by using the token’s length or the minimum of the two lengths, or by checking lengths first). If the macros are implemented safely (limit compare length to token size or otherwise prevent out-of-bounds reads), then no violation occurs; but as written the code can lead to an out-of-bounds access depending on the macro expansion, so the agent’s claim is valid.
